In the letter to his sister, Walker described three parties he attended, people he encountered in his travels and, briefly, a hunting trip to Lookout Mountain. The planter's diary registers the day-to-day operations of the plantation, illnesses of slaves, types of crops grown, as well as travels to town transporting Confederate tithes. In addition to inventories of belongings and financial records from the settlement of the estate, the estate account contains notes on estate laws and settlement concerns (in shorthand), along with slave lists (often giving ages and appraised value; includes accounts of runaways), and a Walker family genealogy.

creator: Markham family.

creator: McBain, Margaret.
title: Margaret McBain diary, 1833-1847.
context_snippet: as painting, sighting seaweeds or fish, and passing notable landmarks. Brackets denote newsworthy events. The ship's
field_content: Collection comprises Margaret McBain's travel diary (26 pgs.) of her sail from Madras to Philadelphia in 1833 aboard the American ship Star. An initial entry lists her traveling companions: "2 Elephants, a pair of Leopards, a Porcupine, anacondas, Monkeys, and several varieties of birds...." Entries primarily record nautical information, including wind and weather conditions, navigation coordinates, and settings of the sails. Occasional entries detail activities on board, such as painting, sighting seaweeds or fish, and passing notable landmarks. Brackets denote newsworthy events. The ship's carpenter falls ill and dies, the cat is lost overboard, and they learn "that Jackson is President" in an exchange of news with another vessel. On the last day of February the ship stops at St. Helena, at which point McBain gives the coordinate position, size, and a brief history of the island. McBain uses six detailed pen-and-ink drawings to illustrate her account, including the ship Star, Mogul the Elephant, the island of St. Helena, and a two-page world map showing the voyage's route. She does not record the reason for her journey, and notes only that she thinks a great deal about her mother and sisters in India, and hopes to be reunited with them in two to three years. The rest of the volume (57 pgs) features original and copied verse recorded long after her travel (1838-1847). Topics focus on nostalgia and the sorrow caused by farewells, departures, and separation.

creator: Reitz, Rosetta. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n85386934
title: Rosetta Reitz papers, 1929-2008.
context_snippet: founder and owner of Rosetta Records, a company most prominent in the 1980s that was dedicated to re-releasing
field_content: Business owner, stock broker, university lecturer, and writer on issues including food, feminism, women's health, and female jazz and blues musicians. She was also the founder and owner of Rosetta Records, a company most prominent in the 1980s that was dedicated to re-releasing historic recordings by female jazz and blues musicians.

creator: J. Walter Thompson Company. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50062749
title: [Admittance cards] 1811-1880.
context_snippet: England). They contain the autographs of the most eminent professors of the day: i.e., Samuel Gross,
field_content: .Admittance, matriculation, and "Order of Lecture" cards are from a number of medical students from 1811-1880 in the University of Pennsylvania, Jefferson Medical College, Long Island College Hospital (Brooklyn, N.Y.), Harvard University Medical School, Philadelphia School of Anatomy, New Hampshire Medical Institution, Berkshire Medical Institution, and St. Bartholomew's Hospital (London, England). They contain the autographs of the most eminent professors of the day: i.e., Samuel Gross, Franklin Bache, Benjamin Rush, Austin Flint, Samuel Jackson, S. Weir Mitchell, J. K. Mitchell, Charles D. and James A Meigs, John Barclay Biddle, et al. The St. Bartholomew's Hospital card is signed by Ludford Harvey, John P. Vicent, and John Abernethy, the latter (1764-1831) being an eminent English surgeon and founder of the Medical School of St Bartholomew's. The "Order of Lecture" cards from Jefferson Medical College and the University of Pennsylvania list curricula, faculty and their residences, schedules of lectures and texts. Admittance cards, 1850-1853, are for courses at the Jefferson Medical School in Philadelphia. They include two matriculation cards for William D. Watson of Chatham County, N. C., dated Nov., 1850, and Oct., 1852, and an examination card Oct., 1852-1853, which is signed by Dr. S. Weir Mitchell as professor of Anatomy, Surgery and Physiology. Dr. Watson returned to Chatham County after his graduation. His house was destroyed during the Civil War. The portion of his medical library saved and stored in a neighboring attic eventually was placed in the historical Collection of the library of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School.

creator: Foundation for Southeast Asian Art and Culture. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2003008217
title: Foundation for Southeast Asian Art and Culture records, 1954-2002.
context_snippet: significant portion of the collection was donated to two museums distinguished for their collections of Southeast Asian art; the Asian
field_content: On a 1957 trip to India and China, Doris Duke stopped in Thailand, and it is likely that the exploration of Bangkok and its art and architecture she saw on that visit inspired her to dream of creating a Thai village in Hawaii with houses similar to those she had seen. In December of 1960, she formally hired Francois Duhau de Berenx to help bring it to pass. The Thai House Foundation was established on January 30, 1961, the name was changed to the Foundation for Southeast Asian Art and Culture (SEAAC) in June of that same year. The establishment of the Foundation resulted in a project that Doris Duke saw as a gift to Hawaii, and one that occupied her for many years. At least five sites in Hawaii were considered for the Thai Village and it was the choice of an appropriate location that ultimately proved the stumbling block to completion of the project. Although her dream of a Thai Village was never fulfilled, Doris Duke's interest in Asia continued, as she continued purchasing objects right up until her death in 1993. In 2002, a significant portion of the collection was donated to two museums distinguished for their collections of Southeast Asian art; the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco and the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore.

field_content: The Doris Duke Memorabilia Collection is contains personal artifacts belonging to Doris Duke. The artifacts widely vary, yet tend to reflect what was important to Miss Duke including travel, philanthropy, growing orchids, and music. Of particular interest are those items from Doris Duke's childhood including scrapbooks, yearbooks, and homework assignments.

creator: Bart, Pauline. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80037810
title: Pauline Bart papers, 1925-2008, 1969-2005.
context_snippet: , drafts of Bart's book, Stopping Rape: Successful Survival Strategies, drafts and published copies of articles and
field_content: The Pauline Bart papers are arranged into five series. The Personal Files Series contains correspondence, appointment books, diaries, peer-reviewed mansucripts for which Bart served as a referee, and other material related to Bart's personal and professional life. The Writings Series contains drafts and copies of reviews, drafts of Bart's book, Stopping Rape: Successful Survival Strategies, drafts and published copies of articles and academic papers written by Bart; and other materials related to her writings. The Teaching Materials Series contains papers related to classes taught by Bart. The Research Files Series contains interview transcripts, content analysis, and other papers related to the Jane Collective, materials related to Stopping Rape: Successful Survival Strategies, interview transcripts and other papers related to a study of depression, and other research files. The Audiotapes series contains recordings of talks given by Bart, conference sessions, presentations, interviews, and classes conducted at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

creator: National Cash Register Company. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79068438
title: D. T. Suzuki Documentary Project collection, 2003-2010.
context_snippet: Eastern religions and teaching at Columbia University. An enormously influential figure, he is cited by artists and thinkers as
field_content: D.T. Suzuki was a scholar of Zen Buddhism, often attributed with introducing Zen to the West. He was born in Japan in 1870, and after working as a translater in the United States, began writing books and essays about Zen. He spent much of his life traveling around the United States speaking about Eastern religions and teaching at Columbia University. An enormously influential figure, he is cited by artists and thinkers as disparate as Carl Jung and John Cage as an important influence on their work.

creator: North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance Company (Durham, N.C.)
title: North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance Company Archives, 1850, 1888-2000s and undated, bulk 1920-2008.
context_snippet: Review (1925-1998). It is also notable for its assemblage of material on United States African American
field_content: The North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance Company Archives documents the development of N.C. Mutual in Durham, N.C., and contributes to the historic record on African American businesses and entrepreneurship in the South and in the United States. Dating from 1850 to 2008, with the majority of the items created from 1920-2008, the material covers nearly every aspect of N.C. Mutual's operations, management, and milestones. Documents take the form of corporate office files, including the offices of five company presidents; annual statements; reports; surveys; memos; legal and financial papers; original life insurance policies; training material; programs; ephemera and artifacts; and a large number of historical photographs of staff and their families, offices, buildings, and Durham scenes. Significant businessmen represented in the papers include founders John Merrick and Aaron Moore; and presidents Bert Collins, Joseph Goodloe, William Kennedy Jr., William Kennedy, III, Charles C. Spaulding, Asa T. Spaulding, and current president James H. Speed. The collection is especially rich in print material, including many issues of three company publications: The Mutual (1903-1929), The Whetstone (1924-1998), and The Weekly Review (1925-1998). It is also notable for its assemblage of material on United States African American history, including much information on other companies, and public relations material dating from the earliest years to present times, including advertising ephemera, advertising campaigns, and other related items. Other materials document North Carolina Mutual's outreach to the African American community throughout its history to counter racism, unemployment, and diseases by means of public health programs, church affiliations, mentoring, and scholarship programs. Over one hundred selected digitized photographs and a few documents are also available online. Acquired and curated jointly by the North Carolina Central University's University Archives, Records and History Center and the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture at Duke University.

creator: Cheston, James, 1747-1798, creator.
title: James Cheston papers, 1771-1784.
context_snippet: , and Thomas Smith. It made clear that the Revolutionary War and interfered with the settlement of the debt.
field_content: Collection comprises a letter book, account book, license, legal document, and letter related to Cheston's work. The letter book (23 April 1771-29 April 1773) recorded Cheston's regular letters to the Stevenson, Randolph & Cheston firm in England, which averaged three to five days apart. The main topics were shipments to and from Baltimore, Md., as well as current prices for incoming and outgoing cargo, including convict servants and products arriving from England; slaves from the West Indies and Africa; and tobacco, corn, wheat requisitioned locally to be sold in England. Upon their arrival, Cheston noted the state of each ship and its passengers. He commented in several letters that recent changes in shipbuilding decreased ventilation below deck; he believed this resulted in more rapid spread of illness or disease aboard, as well as more deaths, and urged a return to former building practices. Several letters go on to document ships that were quarantined as a result of disease and deaths aboard. He also made regular notes of debits and credits to various accounts for the firm, and defended his purchases and business decisions to his partners. The account book (29 March 1784-27 May 1784) documented Cheston's warehouse accounts, including those with the Galloway & Cheston firm he set up with his father-in-law, Samuel Galloway. Entries tracked a wide range of items sold, including rum, corn, butter, and sugar. The license (27 June 1772) was probably drafted on the order of Maryland's governor, and permitted Captain Simon Breffitt (of the ship Elizabeth) to unload cargo and passengers that had been quarantined because typhus aboard had killed 18 servants and the boatswain. In his letter book, Cheston followed the situation, and noted his lobbying for the license. The legal document (14 March 1785) was drafted by George Buck in Devon, Eng., and appointed Cheston his representative in Maryland to handle the debt of Emory Sudder, Joseph Earle, and Thomas Smith. It made clear that the Revolutionary War and interfered with the settlement of the debt. The letter (21 June [1780?]) was written by Cheston to "Jack" in reference to local distillery accounts.

creator: Barrow, Lionel C., 1926-2009, creator.
title: Lionel Barrow papers, 1930s-2008.
context_snippet: Black Journalists, and other conferences and organizations. Another notable component of the collection is the section of materials from
field_content: Collection includes materials from Barrow's advertising career, his teaching and tenure at Howard University, and his involvement in the Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication (AEJMC). The earliest materials include student work from Barrow's youth and his studies at Morehouse College, as well as materials from his service in the 24th Infantry Regiment during the Korean War. The Korean War material, 1950-1951, includes press releases, written by Barrow, regarding various battles and engagements with Communists. Also included is correspondence to his mother, Wilhelmina Barrow, discussing his activities, as well as his struggles with payment and segregation in the U.S. Army. AEJMC materials include a diversity survey from 2004, Minorities and Communications Division files, and programs and reports from organization activities in the 1970s and 1980s. Another significant portion of the collection is Barrow's newspaper clippings and subject files, dating largely from the 1960s-2000s. His research on the Freedom's Journal is also a large component of the collection. Also included are numerous photographs, some dating as early as the 1950s, but the bulk of which date 1982-2000s. These include family vacations and events, as well as professional events with AEJMC, the National Association of Black Journalists, and other conferences and organizations. Another notable component of the collection is the section of materials from Barrow's mother, Wilhelmina Barrow, who served as an American Red Cross Girl in Europe during World War II and the post-war period. Her materials also include some reports and clippings from her membership in the National Council of Negro Women in the 1950s-1960s. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Parry, Elizabeth. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nb2012008984
title: Elizabeth Parry bill of cost in the time of her lying in of an Eligetimate child, about 1730.
context_snippet: go to authority to make complaint of Edward Dix the father of my above[said] child." The bill is signed
field_content: Collection comprises a 1-page bill detailing the costs incurred by Parry during childbirth, including charges for a midwife; food and board; sugar, bread, spices, oatmeal and fruit; a "watch on fixed nights" and candles; the child's linen and clothing; two cords of firewood; a fire wood cutter; and two trips to Boston during the lying-in. Also includes the cost of "time spent to go to authority to make complaint of Edward Dix the father of my above[said] child." The bill is signed by Parry, and witnessed by John Phillips, Joseph Lynde, Jonas Bond, and Edward Emerson.

creator: Samuelson, Paul A. (Paul Anthony), 1915-2009, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50019332 creator.
title: Paul A. Samuelson papers, 1933-2010.
context_snippet: to 2010, and cover nearly all aspects of his distinguished career. Materials are arranged in the original order maintained
field_content: The Paul Samuelson Papers span the years 1933 to 2010, and cover nearly all aspects of his distinguished career. Materials are arranged in the original order maintained by Samuelson, and include his professional correspondence files; unpublished writings, notes, drafts and fragments; audiovisual materials; documents regarding awards, including the Nobel Prize; files relating to various grants, committees, and projects; teaching materials from his years at MIT; files of speeches; and publication files, including professional and mainstream media articles. Significant correspondents include Milton Friedman, Don Patinkin, and Robert Solow, as well as many other notable economists, Nobel prize winners, politicians, and scientists. Material can also be found on economic programs at institutions such as MIT, where Samuelson established a renowned economics faculty. Topics reflected in the papers include: the history of economic thought (post-Keynesian economics, neoclassical economics, and thinkers such as Marx, Sraffa and Ricardo), financial economics, growth theory, international finance, inflation, stability, welfare economics, post-World War economic policies and stabilization, stochastic analysis, utility, monetary policy, Marxist economics, biological economics - including population and gender studies, thermodynamics, and mathematical economics. Samuelson's insights on many of these subjects serve as organizational themes for large sections in the Unpublished Writings Series in the collection. Finally, the Samuelson Papers also document his work for the Federal Reserve, and to federally-funded projects, professional committees and boards, and organizations and societies, beginning in the 1940s and continuing throughout his career. Forms part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.

creator: Teevan, W. F. (William Frederick), 1834-1887.
title: William Frederick Teevan medical case register for St. Peter's Hospital, 1872 June - 1879 July.
context_snippet: Odessa during the Crimean War. Teevan was a highly respected surgeon, but his career was cut short when he
field_content: William Frederick Teevan was a London urologist, andrologist and surgeon. He was educated at University College, and his final posts were at West London and St. Peter's Hospitals. He served in the Civil Hospital in Odessa during the Crimean War. Teevan was a highly respected surgeon, but his career was cut short when he lost his sight (1883), then suffered heart disease and a mental breakdown prior to his death.

creator: Taggart, John Henry, 1821- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr92031534
title: Order book, 1861 August 16 - 1862 April 10.
context_snippet: , orders of the day, establishment of a "pioneer squad," mail regulations, prohibitions on food sold
field_content: Volume comprises an order book (22 pgs.) containing 48 orders, as well as other directives from Taggart. Most were issued at various camps in Washington, D.C., including McCall, Tenally, and Pierpont, as well as Alexandria, Va. Topics include detailing of camp guards, camp life and sanitation, orders of the day, establishment of a "pioneer squad," mail regulations, prohibitions on food sold by sutlers or citizens, recruiting matters, card playing and gambling, the prohibition of Zouave or slouch hats, and resignations by officers. The order dated 1 Nov. records a possible alarm to be sounded following "an advance towards our camp by the enemy during the night." Also includes a chart enumerating the parts of uniforms owned by individual officers in the regiment.

field_content: Paul Jeffrey is a jazz saxophonist. Thelonious Monk (born Rocky Mount, N.C., 10 Oct 1917; died Englewood, N.J., 17 Feb 1982) was an innovative and highly influential jazz pianist and composer.

creator: Casper, Raymond E.
title: Raymond E. Casper photographs, 1945-1946.
context_snippet: Includes at least two photographs of Mohatma Gandhi. Other notable scenes include holy men and priests; Hindu iconography and
field_content: Collection includes slides, negatives, and prints of Southeast Asia, the majority of which appear to have been taken by Major Raymond E. Casper. The slides have not been sleeved, but each box is fairly well-labeled. Slides are in both color and black-and-white. The photographic prints are entirely black-and-white photography, ranging in size between 2x3 to 5x7 inches. They are in good condition, many including Casper's captions with comments, locations, and dates for the image. The images in the collection consist largely of scenes from rural and urban life in Southeast Asia in the mid-1940s. Locations represented include the Karachi Air Base in Pakistan; Lalmonirhat, Bangladesh; Agra, Cooch Behar (Koch Bihar), Calcutta, Hyderabad, and Delhi, India; and Hiroshima, Japan. Includes at least two photographs of Mohatma Gandhi. Other notable scenes include holy men and priests; Hindu iconography and gods; temples and historic sites, including the Taj Mahal and the Jain temple in Calcutta; and archeological sites. Street scenes of everyday people include images of beggars, a leper colony, street doctors and dentists, farmers, water-carriers, snake charmers, launderers, barbers, rickshaws, and policemen. Also includes images of military bases and soldiers, including many images of Casper. Practices that are heavily documented include burning ghats, fuel production from cow manure, and funeral rites. There is also a small amount of photographs from Hiroshima, Japan, showing the devestation of the city following the atomic bomb. A small amount of slides are clearly from a different period of Casper's life. They are in color and have images of a family touring various landmarks in the Eastern United States, including Washington D.C., Luray Caverns, and other historic sites in Virginia. These images are undated.

creator: Turner, Philip, 1740-1815. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2010193901
title: Philip Turner papers, 1751-1858, 1881 and undated.
context_snippet: Dearborn, John Morgan, William Shippen, and other prominent Americans. Also includes materials on Turner's family.
field_content: The Philip Turner Papers span the years from 1751 to 1858 and contain correspondence, military hospital returns, printed material, a logbook, and ledgers documenting Philip Turner's career as a surgeon in private practice in Norwich, Connecticut and New York, New York, in the Continental Army, and in the United States Army. Items include correspondence with George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, William Eustis, Henry Dearborn, John Morgan, William Shippen, and other prominent Americans. Also includes materials on Turner's family. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: Turner, Philip, 1740-1815. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2010193901
title: Philip Turner papers, 1751-1858, 1881 and undated.
context_snippet: Philip Turner (1740-1815) was a noted Revolutionary-era surgeon from Norwich, Connecticut and New York
field_content: Philip Turner (1740-1815) was a noted Revolutionary-era surgeon from Norwich, Connecticut and New York, New York.

creator: Pol, Heinz, 1901-1972. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2006009481
title: Heinz Pol illustrated manuscript Wunsch und Klage, 1940s.
context_snippet: journalist, poet, and film critic. He was prominent literary figure in interwar Germany, and served as editor
field_content: Heinz Pol was a German émigré journalist, poet, and film critic. He was prominent literary figure in interwar Germany, and served as editor of a number of left-wing periodicals, including VOSSLSCHE ZEITUNG (1923-1931) and the satirical magazine SIMPLICISSIMUS (1934-1935). A vocal anti-Fascist, Pol was forced into excile in 1933 following Hitler's rise to power. After a brief internment in a French concentration camp at the beginning of WWII, Pol was able to obtain a visa for the United States in 1940, and he lived there until his death. He was author of several books in English that analyzed the rise of Fascism in Europe, SUICIDE OF A DEMOCRACY and HIDDEN ENEMIES, and was a frequent contributor to THE NATION and other left-of-center periodicals.

creator: Chisholm, Benjamin Ogden, 1865-1944.
title: Benjamin Ogden Chisholm sample book, 1920s-1940s.
context_snippet: a reputation as a tireless prison reformer and penal system expert. In 1908 Chisholm was appointed to the executive board
field_content: A Long Island native and an affluent banker, Benjamin Ogden Chisholm earned a reputation as a tireless prison reformer and penal system expert. In 1908 Chisholm was appointed to the executive board of the New York Prison Association. Educating himself upon the subject of America's penal institutions, he traveled extensively to American prisons and lectured widely on prison reform. Between 1923 and 1930, appointed by President Coolidge, Chisholm served as the United States representative to the International Prison Commission.

creator: Frankland, Abraham E. (Abraham Ephraim), 1831- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n98022693
title: Abraham Ephraim Frankland autobiographical memoir, testament, and family record book, 1863-1912.
context_snippet: Israel, later the Reformed Congregation. Frankland became a prominent citizen, and when he moved to Chicago in the
field_content: Abraham Ephraim Frankland was born in Liverpool, England, but became a naturalized American citizen. He was educated in New York, then in 1845 the Frankland family moved to Nashville, Tenn., where they were among the first permanent Jewish settlers. In March 1850 the family moved to Memphis, where Frankland was a shopkeeper and a partner in a firm of auctioneers and commission merchants dealing in real estate, slaves, furniture, and groceries. He was a confederate sympathizer during the Civil War and a leader in Memphis' Jewish congregation, the Children of Israel, later the Reformed Congregation. Frankland became a prominent citizen, and when he moved to Chicago in the 1880s, the city of Memphis gave him a farewell banquet and presented him with a gold medal.

creator: Blackman Company.
title: Miscellaneous French documents, 1781-1918.
context_snippet: the documents are written by or are addressed to fairly prominent historical figures: British Ambassador Charles Stuart, Minister of
field_content: Collection contains fourteen French documents written between the 18th century and the 20th century. The contents of these documents are broad in scope from sales accounts to personal letters to official government documents. Of note are several documents that refer to American cities such as Augusta, Baltimore, Philadelphia, and Savannah. Several of the documents are written by or are addressed to fairly prominent historical figures: British Ambassador Charles Stuart, Minister of the Interior Alexandre-Auguste Ledru Rollin, General Joseph Léopold Sigisbert (Hugo), and Cardinal Jean-Sifrein Maury.

creator: Kaplan, Kivie, 1904-1975. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n94073617
title: Kivie Kaplan papers, 1968-1971.
context_snippet: King, Jr., the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and prominent civil rights activists in Mississippi and Chicago. The letters
field_content: This collection contains correspondence and associated materials of Kivie Kaplan, president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) from 1966 to 1975. The bulk of the materials are sixteen of Kaplan's letters sent to Harold Gilden, a noted Chicago labor attorney. The letters span the years 1968 to 1971 and provide information about the activities of Kivie Kaplan, while at the NAACP headquarters and speaking to gatherings around the country. Among the people referenced in the letters are Martin Luther King, Jr., the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and prominent civil rights activists in Mississippi and Chicago. The letters also discuss Kaplan's philanthropic activities. The collection also includes eight separately printed items related to the NAACP and the civil rights movement and two NAACP 'Life Member' plaques. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African-American History and Culture.

creator: Barker, Hiram.
title: Hiram Barker papers, 1857-1895 and undated.
field_content: Prominent businessman and banker from Farmington, New Hampshire; established and managed multiple business investments in New Hampshire, the Dakota Territory, Florida, Iowa, Illinois, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, and Minnesota in the 19th century.

creator: Powell, Richard J., 1953- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n87873944
title: Richard Powell papers, 1960-2011.
context_snippet: The Richard Powell Papers document Powell's career as a prominent scholar of African and African American art and professor of
field_content: The Richard Powell Papers document Powell's career as a prominent scholar of African and African American art and professor of Art History at Duke University. The collection contains papers dated from 1960 to 2011, with the bulk of the material dated between 1975 and 2011. The collection includes documentation of Powell's student years, travels, research, correspondence, and work at various cultural institutions including Duke University, the Smithsonian American Art Museum, and the Washington Project for the Arts. The collection includes extensive materials on Powell's books, exhibitions, and other professional activities. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Spinks, John. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n87130860
title: History of Medicine picture file, 1523-2002 and undated.
context_snippet: of medicine and medical practice. The great majority portray notable physicians, scientists, naturalists, philosophers, and other
field_content: Assembled by the staff of the Duke University Medical Library, the History of Medicine Picture File holds thousands of small and large images organized into series for individuals, places, and subjects related to the history of medicine and medical practice. The great majority portray notable physicians, scientists, naturalists, philosophers, and other individuals with important links to medicine. Places featured include hospitals and other institutions of medicine, and scenes in specific locations related to events in medical history. The subject categories cover many topics, with the largest groups including advertising, anatomy, caricatures, cartoons, pediatrics, physicians, and surgery. Predominant formats are engravings, lithographs, print materials (such as posters, clippings, and postcards), and many modern photographic reproductions of older works; there are also albumen photographs, negatives, slide reproductions, and other image formats found throughout the files. Languages other than English include French, German, Italian, Dutch, and Latin. Aquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

title: History of Medicine picture file, 1523-2002 and undated.
context_snippet: scientists, naturalists, philosophers, and other individuals with important links to medicine. Places featured include hospitals and other

creator: National Coalition for Haitian Rights (United States), http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2009096889 creator.
title: National Coalition for Haitian Rights records, 1968-2008, bulk 1982-2004.
context_snippet: in Haiti, the US, and the Caribbean. Important sections include Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haitian migrant workers
field_content: The NCHR records span the years 1982 to 2004 and contain the organization's administrative records, program and project files, legal files, extensive subject files, as well as a large collection of print materials. NCHR maintained offices in New York City and in Port-au-Prince. The files in the NCHR records are largely those of the New York office, but there is also extensive overlap with the activities and files of the Haiti office. Key Haiti activities documented include human rights training, monitoring and reporting, judicial and penitentiary reform, Haitian National Police monitoring, and returning refugee monitoring and advocacy. Key US activities documented include Haitian community development, promoting and protecting rights of Haitian immigrants, promoting naturalization and citizenship, and educating Haitians on government services and citizenship. The Administrative series documents the management and day-to-day operations of NCHR. These files include organizational planning, board of directors, development, and operational files. The Program and Projects series contains the files produced by NCHR's major programmatic work: The Community Action Program (CAP), the Haitian-American Community Action Network (HACAN), Legal Education and Assistance Project (LEAP), and Restavek. The Legal series contains files related to NCHR's work on broad legal cases effecting US immigration policy and human rights accountability in Haiti, as well as legal support NCHR provided to individuals, largely related to immigration and asylum in the US. The William O'Neill Files series documents O'Neill's work for NCHR, primarily related to the United Nations mission to Haiti. The Subject Files series is the largest series in the collection, documenting a wide variety of NCHR's work in Haiti, the US, and the Caribbean. Important sections include Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haitian migrant workers in the Bahamas and the Dominican Republic, "Boat People" and interdiction, elections in Haiti, Guantanamo and Krome detention centers, and police reform. The Subject Files series may overlap with many of the other series in the collection. The Print Material series contains an extensive collection of reports, newsletters, bulletins, and other publications primarily concerning human rights and Haitians. These materials compliment the other series in this collection, particularly the Subject Files. The Audiovisual series contains videos, photos, and audiotapes documenting NCHR's work. Key figures documented in the collection include Prosper Avril, Anthony J. Bevilacqua, Anne Fuller, Michael S. Hooper, Jocelyn McCalla, and Bayard Rustin. Organizations covered include Caribbean Rights, Haitian Center for Human Rights, Komité National du Kongrés des Mouvements Démocratiques, and Ligue des Anciens Prisonniers Politiques Haïtiens. Additional topics include HIV and AIDS, migrant labor, and judicial corruption.

creator: Stevenson John (John Alun)
title: John Stevenson Papers 1947-1983 and undated.
context_snippet: which specialized
field_content: Pioneer in direct mail, director of Greystone Press which specialized in subscription encyclopedias and continuity series books.

creator: Couper (Family)
title: Altama plantation and Couper family photographs and reunion scrapbook, 1900-1940.
context_snippet: James Hamilton Couper (1794-1866), a planter who acquired his wife's interest in Hopeton Plantation,
field_content: The Couper family includes descendents of James Hamilton Couper (1794-1866), a planter who acquired his wife's interest in Hopeton Plantation, on the Altamaha River near Brunswick, Georgia, around 1827. In 1857 he and his wife occupied their new home there, which they called "Altama." Their slaves numbered up to 1500.

creator: Bastian, H. Charlton. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n83237219
title: Henry Charlton Bastian papers, 1841-1932 and undated.
context_snippet: . The largest series contains correspondence between Bastian and other prominent scientists, neurologists, scholars, publishers, assistants,
field_content: The collection documents Bastian's rise as a neuroscientist, biologist, writer, and reseacher, and encompasses typed and manuscript letters to and from Bastian, research notes and writings, scientific photographs, ink and pencil drawings, and professional reviews and accolades. The largest series contains correspondence between Bastian and other prominent scientists, neurologists, scholars, publishers, assistants, and friends, including Louis Pasteur, Caleb Saleeby, Thomas Huxley, Sir John Bretland Farmer, Aristide Pratelle, and William Paton Ker, among many others. There are also exchanges with the Académie des Sciences in France. The correspondence usually concerns Bastian's research projects and publishing activities, particularly his work on abiogenesis, but also on paralysis. Other materials are more personal, and include obituaries, condolences, Christmas cards, and newspaper clippings. The collection also contains numerous pieces of correspondence addressed to Bastian's daughter, Sybil Bastian, who was also a scientist, and Bastian's wife Julia. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: Bastian, H. Charlton. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n83237219
title: Henry Charlton Bastian papers, 1841-1932 and undated.
context_snippet: active in the late
field_content: Prominent British neuroscientist, scientist and writer active in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

creator: Bryn, Doris.
title: Doris Bryn Papers, 1939-1998 and undated.
field_content: Doris Bryn (nee Krehnbrink) was a prominent fashion and cover model during the 1940s-1960s and co-designer of several lines of fashion accessories with her husband Roger Vsn Schoyck under the brand names Roger Van S. and Mr. R.

creator: Jackson, Kate. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nb99178852
title: Kate Brigham Jackson letters, 1911, 1926.
context_snippet: wife of Abraham Valentine Williams Jackson, who was a pioneer of Iranian studies in America and professor of Indo-
field_content: Kate Jackson was born Kate O'Brien Brigham in 1870 in Savannah, Georgia. She was well educated, studied at the Sorbonne, and was a member of the American Oriental Society. She translated from French to English a book on Persian poetry by James Darmesteter. In 1911, she became the second wife of Abraham Valentine Williams Jackson, who was a pioneer of Iranian studies in America and professor of Indo-Iranian languages at Columbia University.

creator: Mitchell, John Kearsley, 1793-1858. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86803051
title: Lectures on the Theory and Practice of Medicine, circa 1850.
field_content: Mitchell was a notable physician and educator teaching at Jeffereson Medical College in Philadelphia. Fitts was an Alabamian physician educated in Philadelphia and practicing in Carroll County, Mississippi in the mid-19th century.

creator: Rush, Benjamin, 1746-1813. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50000649
title: Notes on Rush's Lectures, circa 1799-1809.

field_content: Bound volume of typed correspondence from members of the U.S. House and Senate consisting of inquiries sent to physicians by congressmen requesting expert medical opinion on legislative or constituent concerns.

creator: Physick, Philip Syng, 1768-1837. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84027159
title: Lectures on surgery by Philip S. Physick and John S. Dorsey, 1811-1812.
context_snippet: the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia; dubbed "The Father of American Surgery." John Syng Dorsey was also an
field_content: Philip Syng Physick was a noted surgeon on staff at Pennsylvania Hospital and professor of medicine at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia; dubbed "The Father of American Surgery." John Syng Dorsey was also an American-born physician; in 1804 he returned from studies in London to assist Physick at the new Pennsylvania Hospital, and also became a professor at the University of Pennsylvania. He died of typhus in 1818.

creator: Collier, George Ralph, Sir, 1774-1824.
title: George Ralph Collier Memo of Instructions to convoy of British trading ships, 1821 February 12.
context_snippet: was an officer of the Royal Navy during the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, and the War of 1812.
field_content: Sir George R. Collier was an officer of the Royal Navy during the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, and the War of 1812.

creator: Scarlett, M. J. (Mary J.) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2012184530
title: Mary J. Scarlett letters and broadside, 1845-1864 and undated.
context_snippet: concern that the Army of the Potomac needed to be successful, and pointed to camps nearby as well as to
field_content: Collection contains seven letters (22 pages) M. J. Scarlett wrote between 1845-1864. Two letters were addressed to her sister, Elizabeth (1845, 1849), and five to her niece (1858, 1860, 1863, 1864). In the letters she discussed details of her life at the time, from the teaching of students to the choosing of proper fabric for sewing a dress, making a comfortable sitting room, or studying public health and hygiene. She also mentioned many family matters. She commented on her hopes for the abolition of slavery and the infighting among abolitionists at a recent national meeting, and noted her puzzlement that those Quakers who would quickly speak as abolitionists would not also speak up on issues of faith within the Society of Friends. During the Civil War, she described the effect of the draft in Philadelphia, recorded the general concern that the Army of the Potomac needed to be successful, and pointed to camps nearby as well as to funerals passing. Collection also includes an undated broadside for "An Introductory Lecture to a Course on Physiology" to be delivered by Scarlett. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections (Duke University), the Lisa Unger Baskin Collection, and the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Newman, F. W. (Francis William), 1805-1897. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50005229
title: Francis William Newman letters, 1840-1887.
context_snippet: letters by Newman, including a congratulatory letter to a successful former student regarding forming regular habits of study, and
field_content: Collection comprises five letters by Newman, including a congratulatory letter to a successful former student regarding forming regular habits of study, and a formal letter regarding moral and religious truth and its place in the study of the Bible to a student seeking his opinion. There are also three letters on British politics and public opinion regarding continental politics, particularly events in Venice, Austria, and Italian unification. Two of these letters are addressed to Mrs. Schwabe, and the other was mailed as a personal opinion letter to the editor of the Daily Mail.

creator: Myers, C. W. (Charles Wesley), 1890-1985.
title: Charles W. Myers case reports manuscripts, 1928-1932.
context_snippet: Medical Corps during World War I, and received the Distinguished Service Cross and the Croix de Guerre (twice)
field_content: Dr. Charles Wesley Myers was a physician and hospital administrator. He was born in Marysville, Pennsylvania, and graduated from the University of Maryland School of Medicine in 1915. He served in the Army Medical Corps during World War I, and received the Distinguished Service Cross and the Croix de Guerre (twice) from France. Following the war, he became a surgeon for the U.S. Vetrans Bureau in Indianapolis, Indiana, before moving to City Hospital, there. During his tenure there as superintendent and medical director (1931-1952), Meyers opened new wards for African American patients, appointed blacks to hospital staff positions, and oversaw the construction of improved special care facilitites.

creator: Saltar family.
title: Saltar family correspondence, 1759-1880 and undated.
context_snippet: family friends and relatives, male and female, from prominent families in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland, New
field_content: Over 200 pieces of correspondence dating from 1759-1880, written by women of the Saltar and Gordon families of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Maryland between themselves and other family relations. Over a third of the letters date before 1825. The principal correspondents are Elizabeth "Betsy" Gordon Saltar, her daughters Lucy Saltar and Frances "Fanny" Saltar, and Elizabeth's cousins Mary Gordon and Polly Gordon. Dozens of other letters come from family friends and relatives, male and female, from prominent families in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland, New York, and some from the Midwest and New England states. Topics include courtship; marriage; religion; pastimes; visits and travel; and the welfare of family members and friends. There are many references to illnesses, with many details on treatments and outcomes. There are also long passages and references to grief and mourning on the death of loved ones, and some discussions of finances. There are a few references to slavery and to enslaved people and servants. Letters sent during the Civil War discuss events centered around Pennsylvania, particularly in 1863; one discusses African American troops and their role in the war, and the circumstances surrounding the recruitment of the 3rd United States Colored Troops commander, Benjamin C. Tilghman. A few earlier letters speak of the War of 1812, especially in and around Baltimore and Philadelphia. Acquired by the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Virginia Barber Literary Agency, creator.
title: Virginia Barber Literary Agency records, 1968-2003.
context_snippet: professional organizations such as the Independent Literary Agents Association. Notable clients represented in this collection include Peter Mayle, Anita
field_content: The collection includes client files and correspondence for the VBLA's many clients during the late 1970s through the early 2000s. There are also legal and financial materials, correspondence files with other agencies and publishers, including Virago Press, and materials from Barber's work with professional organizations such as the Independent Literary Agents Association. Notable clients represented in this collection include Peter Mayle, Anita Shreve, MacDonald Harris, Anne Rivers Siddons, James Dodson, Rosellen Brown, and Paul Ehrlich.

creator: Tayloe, Julia Maria.
title: Julia Maria Tayloe notes and invitations to Dolly Madison, 1837.
context_snippet: wife of first wife of Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, a prominent landowner from Virginia who resided in Washington, D. C.
field_content: Julia Maria Tayloe was the first wife of first wife of Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, a prominent landowner from Virginia who resided in Washington, D. C., much of his life and at one time owned the Willard Hotel. The Tayloe and Madison families were close friends for many years. When Dolley Madison returned to Washington after her husband's death, she lived near the Tayloe home on LaFayette Square.

creator: Howard, John, 1962- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n97041657
title: Observations sur les sages-femmes, 1786 Mai 30.
context_snippet: neglected by this national training campaign, and reveals the important differences existing in the kingdom that left it in a
field_content: In early 1786, Calonne, then Controller General of Finance, launched an extensive investigation to assess the number of midwives in France and their levels of training. It was discovered that not all areas of Provence had been provided the training offered by the court-appointed midwife Madame du Coudray between 1759 and 1783, who had been commissioned by Louis XVI to provide it throughout France. The first round of Coudray's training in the region was held in 1780 in Arles and Marseille, and excluded the rest of the province. This statement describes the situation in a rural area neglected by this national training campaign, and reveals the important differences existing in the kingdom that left it in a medical stance equivalent to that in other parts of France before 1750. It also shows how doctors and surgeons placed their own pawns to oust midwives or at least subordinate them.

creator: Longpré, Jean-Baptiste, 1776?-
title: Jean Longpré Haitian independence documents, 1799, 1804.
context_snippet: key Haitian revolutionaries. De la Martinier was a rich plantation owner whose illegitimate mulatto son, Louis Daure Lamartiniere, did
field_content: Collection comprises two documents from a collection of Jean Longpré's papers, including an excerpted copy of a will for Monsieur de la Martinier (1799) and a manuscript copy of Haiti's Declaration of Independence. The extracted will mentions those with family members who became key Haitian revolutionaries. De la Martinier was a rich plantation owner whose illegitimate mulatto son, Louis Daure Lamartiniere, did not inherit due to his mixed race. Lamartiniere and his wife, Jeanne Marie, were key figures in the fight for Haitian independence. In the document, Jacque (sic?) Drouet and Bernard Pemerle are appointed executors of de la Martinier's estate because of assistance they have provided. Drouet or his son was the person for whom Fort Drouet, built in 1804 by General Dessalines, was named. Bernard Pemerle was the father of Martial Pemerle, a noted freedom fighter in the 1790s. Both men signed the document, which also mentions another family (the handwriting is not legible) as recipients of property in Martinique. The contemporary manuscript copy (4 pages; 8 5/8" x 12 3/16") of the Haitian Declaration of Independence begins "Liberté, ou la mort, Armée indigène. Aujourd'hui 1er de Janvier 1804, le Gen en Chef de l'armee indigene, accompagne des Generaux de l'armee, convoques a l'effer de prendre les mesures qui doivener tender au Bonheur du pays ..." The Declaration takes has three parts. In the first part, the Generals of the Haitian army sign their names to an oath swearing to renounce the French yoke or to die rather than to live under French domination. In part two, General-in-Chief Jean-Jacques Dessalines addresses the Haitians in an impassioned defense of independence. Finally, Haitian generals proclaim Dessalines Governor-General for life and swear to obey laws issued under his authority.
