creator: Freeman, A. Myrick, 1936- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50025696
title: Myrick Freeman papers, 1967-2010.
context_snippet: 1970 to 2010 and document Freeman's career as a prominent economist at Bowdoin College and senior fellow at Resources for
field_content: The Myrick Freeman papers date from approximately 1970 to 2010 and document Freeman's career as a prominent economist at Bowdoin College and senior fellow at Resources for the Future in Washington, D.C. The materials in the collection cover Freeman's consulting work, participation in conferences and workshops, writings, as well as testimony for the U.S. Congress and other government entities.

creator: Holt, Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock, 1881-1980.
title: Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock Holt papers, 1889-1980.
context_snippet: the business and financial transactions which she conducted as a prominent landowner in Durham. Materials include correspondence, photographs,
field_content: The Wylanta Duke Strayhorn Aycock Holt Papers date from 1889 to 1980 and chronicle the personal life of Wylanta as well as the business and financial transactions which she conducted as a prominent landowner in Durham. Materials include correspondence, photographs, and financial records.

creator: Diamond, Peter A., http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84007075 creator.
title: Peter Diamond papers, 1963-2013.
context_snippet: 1963 to 2013 and document Diamond's career as a renowned economist whose work has focused on U.S. Social Security policy
field_content: The Peter Diamond papers date from 1963 to 2013 and document Diamond's career as a renowned economist whose work has focused on U.S. Social Security policy and other forms of social insurance. The collection's materials cover Diamond's writings, grants, and participation in lectures, seminars, and other events, as well as Diamond's association with groups such as the National Science Foundation (NSF), the American Association of Retired Persons (AARP), and the National Academy of Social Insurance (NASI). Writings drafts include both paper and electronic formats. Forms part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.

creator: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no99091652
title: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor collection, 1945.
context_snippet: for unity of all our people." Names of prominent sponsors are listed. After the second grand jury meeting
field_content: Collection contains 17 items related to advocacy on behalf of Mrs. Recy Taylor's case, primarily press releases from the Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor and the Alabama Committee for Equal Justice. The press releases in this group reflect the evolution of the case and the committees. The January and early February items remind members of the importance of the case as "a fight for all American womanhood. It is a fight for equal justice and for unity of all our people." Names of prominent sponsors are listed. After the second grand jury meeting on February 14, the press releases take on a more politically forceful tone. Members of local NAACP chapters were joined by members of labor unions and prominent citizens in demanding national action. The Alabama Committee's press releases record the intimidation of their executive secretary Caroline Collier Ballin when she attempted to interview members of Mrs. Taylor's family. Also includes a brochure on the incident with appeals for support, a petition form, a newspaper article on the case from "The Worker," and a flyer on this case and others requiring action to protect civil rights. One press release contains a list of supporters. There is also a custom case created to house the materials. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no99091652
title: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor collection, 1945.
context_snippet: NAACP chapters were joined by members of labor unions and prominent citizens in demanding national action. The Alabama Committee's
field_content: Collection contains 17 items related to advocacy on behalf of Mrs. Recy Taylor's case, primarily press releases from the Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor and the Alabama Committee for Equal Justice. The press releases in this group reflect the evolution of the case and the committees. The January and early February items remind members of the importance of the case as "a fight for all American womanhood. It is a fight for equal justice and for unity of all our people." Names of prominent sponsors are listed. After the second grand jury meeting on February 14, the press releases take on a more politically forceful tone. Members of local NAACP chapters were joined by members of labor unions and prominent citizens in demanding national action. The Alabama Committee's press releases record the intimidation of their executive secretary Caroline Collier Ballin when she attempted to interview members of Mrs. Taylor's family. Also includes a brochure on the incident with appeals for support, a petition form, a newspaper article on the case from "The Worker," and a flyer on this case and others requiring action to protect civil rights. One press release contains a list of supporters. There is also a custom case created to house the materials. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

creator: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no99091652
title: Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor collection, 1945.
context_snippet: membership, local NAACP chapters, labor unions, and prominent citizens, but the case was never brought to trial
field_content: Mrs. Recy Taylor was abducted and raped by six white men in Abbeville, Alabama, on the night of September 3, 1944. Despite admission of guilt by one of the men, who also named the others involved, Henry County's all-white grand jury which convened in October failed to return an indictment. The "Committee for Equal Justice for Mrs. Recy Taylor" was formed a few weeks later, appealing to the Governor of the State to pressure the County to reopen the case. The local chapter of the NAACP, under the leadership of Edgar D. Nixon, helped organize the push for justice (Rosa Parks was working in the NAACP offices during this time and was active in the case). A second grand jury heard the case in February 1945, but again refused to return an indictment. The committee continued to apply pressure through their membership, local NAACP chapters, labor unions, and prominent citizens, but the case was never brought to trial. Many of the organizers used what they learned in subsequent campaigns for civil rights. Recy Taylor and her family lived on in Abbeville for many years, often intimidated and threatened. In 2011, the Alabama's House of Representatives formally apologized to Taylor for the state's failure to prosecute her attackers.

creator: Rimington, William Drewry, 1775-1799.
title: William Drewry Rimington letters, 1799 May-October.
context_snippet: recounts news received in the morning papers, "a gentleman arrived from New York on Friday last we are informed
field_content: Collection comprises three letters written by Rimington, from Cork, Ireland; Boston, Mass.; and Newport, R.I.; describing to his father and brother his outward voyage to America, his first impressions of Boston, and relating news of the spread of yellow fever in New York. There is an additional letter written by Edward Wilson to Rimington's father describing the circumstances of the young man's death from yellow fever in Essex County, N.J. In the first letter, 5th May, Rimington states that they set out from Cork on 31 March, but were forced to return to port after the ship was damaged in a terrible storm, " a gale of wind, which continued 12 days the most tempestuous Captain Tinkham ever experienced though he has crossed the Atlantic thirty six times...." Rimington details the rest of the voyage, including engaging three French privateers and the crew's near mutiny. He penned a second letter to his father upon his arrival in Boston, 4th Aug., and provided his initial impressions of the city, "...the people in general drink a good deal but it is looked upon as actually necessary, they who drank freely was preserved from the yellow fever last year when others who thought of saving themselves by living low fell victims to it." He then outlined his plans for travel to New York and Philadelphia, and on to "Madeira to Cape de Verd & Sandwich Islands also Othate where Ct. Cook was killed--from there to Cape of Good Hope...." Rimington addressed the third letter to his brother, and it is in two sections. The first part is written while he is still in Boston, 29 Aug., and recounts news received in the morning papers, "a gentleman arrived from New York on Friday last we are informed that the yellow fever has again made its appearance and is making an alarming progress in that city and that the inhabitants are leaving in great numbers." He informs his brother that he has already sent his trunks there, so is unfortunately committed to travel there. By the time writes the second section of the letter, 1 Sept., he is ill and confined to his room with a doctor in attendance. Edward Wilson wrote to Michael Rimington, 24 Oct., and described the final care given his son at the house of I. Tuttle in Essex Co., N.J. Includes a typed transcription of the letters. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections.

creator: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79022968 creator.
title: Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle papers, 1820-1927 and undated.
context_snippet: Jane Baillie Welsh in Haddington Scotland) was also a prolific letter-writer.
field_content: Thomas Carlyle (4 December 1795 - 5 February 1881) was a Scottish philosopher, satirical writer, essayist, historian and teacher. His wife, Jane Welsh Carlyle (14 July 1801 - 21 April 1866, née Jane Baillie Welsh in Haddington Scotland) was also a prolific letter-writer.

creator: Dundas, David, 1799-1877. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2010181780
title: David Dundas songs and verses, 1864, 1867 and undated.
context_snippet: a verse in Latin, "The Death of a Respected Thomas Grenville." There is also a copy of
field_content: Collection comprises five songs and verses laid into a presentation copy of SONGS AND VERSES SOCIAL AND SCIENTIFIC presented to Dundas by Lord Charles Neaves. Includes a verse in Latin, "The Death of a Respected Thomas Grenville." There is also a copy of "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star," in Greek; along with "Mr. Buckle," and "To the Wallflower," and a third item whose title is unclear, all in English.

creator: Roane, William, active 1821.
title: William Roane diary, 1813-1821.
context_snippet: aboard the corvette "John Adams," and notes successful appointment to the Superior Court, his illnesses and their
field_content: Collection comprises the diary Roane maintained between 4 October 1813 - 8 August 1821. Entries primarily record his travel as an attorney for various Superior Courts, but he also outlines his service in the United States Navy (1813-1818) aboard the corvette "John Adams," and notes successful appointment to the Superior Court, his illnesses and their treatment, and the names of those he visits.

creator: Dexter, Andrew Alfred, 1809-1854. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr00022218
title: Andrew Alfred Dexter partial letter, 1841 Jan. 1.
context_snippet: the town of Aiken, S.C. He became a cotton planter in Macon County, Ala., but died of yellow
field_content: Andrew Alfred Dexter was a civil engineer. He surveyed first railroad from Charleston, S.C. to Augusta, Ga. and laid out the town of Aiken, S.C. He became a cotton planter in Macon County, Ala., but died of yellow fever while surveying a railroad from Mobile to New Orleans.

creator: Clark, Kenneth Willis, 1898-1979. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n84174751
title: Kenneth W. Clark Civil Defense vertical file, 1942-1943 and undated.
context_snippet: School (1931-1967); he was a renowned textual critic and leading authority on ancient Christian manuscripts.
field_content: Kenneth Willis Clark was a professor of New Testament at Duke Divinity School (1931-1967); he was a renowned textual critic and leading authority on ancient Christian manuscripts. He married Adelaide E. Dickinson; she served as executive secretary for the Durham County Civilian Defense Council.

creator: American Friends of Vietnam. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86054219
title: American Friends of Vietnam collection, 1957-1960.
context_snippet: saving it from Communism. The organization was formed by prominent liberals and conservatives who considered Vietnam a critical contest in
field_content: American Friends of Vietnam was formed in 1955 to promote United States interests in the country, with the specific goal of saving it from Communism. The organization was formed by prominent liberals and conservatives who considered Vietnam a critical contest in the Cold War. Its membership was selective, and included scholars, journalists, business representatives, as well as members of Congress,

creator: Durham Community War Fund.
title: Communist and Socialist songs and lyrics, 1900-1932.
context_snippet: a 70-page songbook, "International collection of revolutionary songs ; International Musical Bureau of I.U.R.T." (Moscow
field_content: Collection comprises song or lyric sheets for nine Communist and Socialist pieces, including the "Internationale"; "March of the Toilers"; "Banker and Boss"; "Men of the Soil"; "Socialist March"; "The Holhen Bride"; "The Banking Song"; "It's a Long, Long Trail Awinding"; and "Babies Just Babies." Most lyrics are in English, but there are a few in German and Italian. There is also a 70-page songbook, "International collection of revolutionary songs ; International Musical Bureau of I.U.R.T." (Moscow: Moscow State Musical Publishing Office, 1933), with the song in its original language, accompanied by translations in English, German, and Russian.

creator: Committee to Defend Francisco Molina. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2008035191
title: Committee to Defend Francisco Molina case description, flyers, and articles, 1961.
context_snippet: the work of the Committee, he was repatriated to revolutionary Cuba in a prisoner exchange for counter-revolutionaries captured
field_content: The Committee to Defend Francisco Molina was formed in 1960. The pro-Castro Francisco Molina, a Cuban American worker from New York, was framed with the death of a Venezuelan girl following a shooting in September 1960. He was arrested and the case went to trial just before the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in April 1961. Molina was convicted, but as a result of the work of the Committee, he was repatriated to revolutionary Cuba in a prisoner exchange for counter-revolutionaries captured during that abortive invasion.

creator: Toy, Eckard Vance, Jr., 1931-2013, collector.
title: Eckard V. Toy Jr. papers, 1920s-1995.
context_snippet: at times include Toy's correspondence with various representatives. Prominent in the collection are the Church of Jesus Christ Christian
field_content: Collection includes Toy's research files and related materials on various extremist groups in the United States, particularly right-wing Christian extremists, the Ku Klux Klan, and Holocaust revisionists. Files are arranged by group or topic and at times include Toy's correspondence with various representatives. Prominent in the collection are the Church of Jesus Christ Christian, various factions of the Ku Klux Klan, the German American National Political Action Committee (GANPAC), the Institute for Historical Review, pro-Aryan white nationalist groups, and Christian Biblical America. Collection also contains Toy's research on Francis Yockey and Gordon Kahl. Materials from the IHR include two VHS tapes and one audiocassette on Holocaust revisionism.

creator: Hozman, Ellsa Lucile.
title: Ellsa Lucile Hozman travel diary, 1913 April 29-1913 August 28.
context_snippet: two sisters, Jennie and Bessie. The family are wealthy and hire a guide for their travel in Spain.
field_content: Collection primarily comprises Ellsa Hozman's travel diary written in ink (85 pages, dated 29 April to 4 July 1913) with diary publisher's title "My Trip Abroad," along with five separate diary pages written in pencil on hotel stationary (dated 11-28 August 1913) and 3 pieces of artwork, all laid-in. The travel diary includes 8 pages printed color lithographs and 12 pages printed information on ships (night signals, time changes, latitudes & longitudes of cities, etc.), as well as a large, folding world map in color bound at the rear of the volume. Ellsa identifies herself on the back of a silhouette of herself in "Quaker costume." She is a young woman traveling in Europe with her parents and two sisters, Jennie and Bessie. The family are wealthy and hire a guide for their travel in Spain. They have friends in many of the cities where they travel, and relatives as well as friends in Berlin. Ellsa describes with great detail their travel in Spain, a country that was likely new to her, including the cities of Algeciras, Tangier, Ronda, Granada, Seville, Cordova, Madrid, Toledo, Escorial, Burgos, San Sabastian, and Barcelona. She used her diary to record much of the history she learned from their guide, along with sites seen, including paintings, as well as a long passage describing a bull fight in Madrid. Her description of the two-day trip to Tangier covers 10 pages, with description of the people, donkeys, and activity in the streets, including a Muslim wedding procession, which leads her into a long passage on Muslim wedding customs. Other cities visited include Gibraltar, Genoa, Milan, Lucerne, Interlaken, Bern, Frankfurt, and Berlin, where her description is more routine, and includes mostly activities like walking, shopping, swimming, going to a "moving picture," and visiting an aquarium, along with frequent visits with relatives and friends. One unexplained event occurred in a Frankfurt hotel, where her mother refuses to stay when she sees a "not wanted" sign. Includes two small drawings of Moorish architecture that were laid-in. The penmanship changes mid-way through the volume, then back again, so it may be that Ellsa shared authorship with her sisters. Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

creator: Hozman, Ellsa Lucile.
title: Ellsa Lucile Hozman travel diary, 1913 April 29-1913 August 28.
field_content: Ellsa Lucile Hozman was a born into a wealthy family from the United States, around 1895.

creator: Lyon, Rosina.
title: Rosina Lyon letters, 1846-1849.
context_snippet: , the romantic possibilities for other family members, the Revolutionary War site in Camden, her prospects for advancement to
field_content: Collection comprises 4 letters written by well-educated individuals, including three directed to Rosina Lyon between 1847 and 1849. There is a letter written by an unnamed writer in Louisville, K.Y (30 Nov. 1847), to "sisters Rosina, Louise, and Cousin Beulah," so most likely from a female family member. She writes of teaching her niece and "two colored pupils residing in the family," along with an additional class of African-American students at the local school, as well as settling in her new place, meeting new people, getting involved in the local sewing circle, and her loving memories of her classmates and teachers at Mount Holyoke. In another letter from Louisville (27 Jan. 1848), "L.," writes about Rosina's dislocated arm, her participation in local "religious awakenings," and describes African-Americans of all ages who attend the local "colored school. All seem interested. There are but few teachers--little interest seems to be felt in teaching the blacks." The third letter to Rosina is written by her brother-in-law in Fellowsville, Va. (17 Dec. 1849) thanking her for her loan of money and assuring it's receipt. He writes that he is a pastor for 3 churches, with additional preaching duties at three other churches per month. There is an additional letter, written 24 Feb. 1846, by Fanny A. Coleman written to Joseph, a childhood friend. Coleman is a teacher working in Camden, S.C. She writes of the changes in Joseph's family life related to from the death of his father and the resulting unsettled estate, her coming status as an "old maid" and what that means to her, the romantic possibilities for other family members, the Revolutionary War site in Camden, her prospects for advancement to the position of principal, and the fact that teaching positions are as plentiful as ever in the South, but the salaries are lower than they have traditionally been.

creator: Bengal Chamber of Commerce and Industry. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50078698
title: Bengal Chamber of Commerce letter of gratitude to Daniel Mackinlay upon his retirement, 1860 February 21.
context_snippet: MAGAZINE described his retirement as follows, "So much esteemed was he by his brother merchants in Calcutta who had
field_content: Collection comprises a letter of recognition and gratitude from members of the Bengal Chamber of Commerce to Daniel Mackinlay, who was retiring as their president and returning to England. The letter is 17x26-inches and is composed of vellum parchment. In 1844 Mackinlay (1810-1882) had been sent to Calcutta to take over management of the firm Gillanders, Arbuthnot, & Co. The letter outlines their esteem, confers their best wishes, and announces their intent to have his portrait painted. It is signed by nine members. In its obituary of Mackinlay in 1882, THE CELTIC MAGAZINE described his retirement as follows, "So much esteemed was he by his brother merchants in Calcutta who had previously conferred upon him the Presidentship of the Chamber of Commerce the highest honour at their disposal that, on his retirement, they had his portrait painted and hung up in their Chamber, while at the same time they presented him with a valuable service of plate, in recognition of his services to his brothers in commerce."

creator: Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies (U.S.), http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no90022649 creator.
title: Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies records, 1966-2014.
context_snippet: . Conferences include forums, roundtables, and speeches from notable figures, elected officials, and congressional members including Maya
field_content: The collection is comprised of JCPES administrative records including correspondence, memorandums, budgets, funding reports, publications, policy research studies, conference materials, photographs, audiovisual media, and electronic files. Areas of study include healthcare, HIV/AIDS, minority business, television violence, young fathers, education, and minority community representation. Among its many publications, JCPES published FOCUS magazine from 1972 to 2011, which covered national issues for an audience largely comprised of black elected officials (BEOs). The collection also includes oral histories of Joint Center founders and influencers, interview transcripts, an extensive history of JCPES, materials from the The Joint Center South Africa office which provided post-Apartheid political assistance activities, and original Southern Regional Council publications. Materials of interest to researchers include the interviews/oral histories with founders Louis Martin, educator Kenneth B. Clark who was the first African American president of the American Psychological Association; and McGeorge Bundy, who served as United States National Security Advisor to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson on foreign and defense policy from 1961 through 1966. Interviews and transcripts that add historical perspective to African American issues are conversations with southern black mayors; African American architect and social activist Carl Anthony; and Ernest Green, one of the Little Rock Nine. Conferences include forums, roundtables, and speeches from notable figures, elected officials, and congressional members including Maya Angelou, Joe Biden, Cory Booker, Edward Brooke, Ron Brown, Carol Moseley Braun, George H.W. Bush, Barbara Bush, Henry Cisneros, Shirley Chisholm, Bill Clinton, Hillary Clinton, Charles Diggs, John Hope Franklin, Jesse Jackson, Maynard Jackson, Valerie Jarrett, Barbara Jordan, Vernon Jordan, Jack Kemp, Coretta Scott King, John Lewis, Eleanor Holmes Norton, Barack Obama, Colin Powell, Charles Rangel, Ronald Reagan, Kasim Reed, Condoleezza Rice, Susan Rice, Donna Shalala, Rodney Slater, Doug Wilder, and Andrew Young. Joint Center historical notes compiled by Darlene Clark Hine are included, as well as Juan Williams' historical publication The Joint Center: Portrait of a Black Think Tank. The files and speeches of Joint Center past presidents Eddie N. Williams; Togo West, Jr.; Ralph Everett, Esq.; and past vice president Eleanor Farrar add insight to the Joint Center's mission of illuminating concerns and trends affecting 20th century African Americans to the legislative influencers most able to effect change.

creator: American Colony. Photography Department.
title: American Colony lantern slides of biblical lands, 1910s-1940s.
context_snippet: community included a cluster of commercial enterprises, the most successful of which was their photography department. Under the leadership
field_content: Based in Jerusalem, the American Colony was founded in 1881 as a utopian Christian community by emigrants from Chicago, United States, who were soon joined by Swedish Christians and other supporters. The community performed many charitable works in the city of Jerusalem and in surrounding areas. Soon the community included a cluster of commercial enterprises, the most successful of which was their photography department. Under the leadership of photographer Elijah Meyers, then Lewis Larsson and G. Eric Matson, the unit expanded and provided a steady income from the sale of souvenir images of the Palestine region, both prints and glass lantern slides. The unit was eventually renamed the Matson Photographic Service. The colony disbanded in the 1950s, but their main headquarters still remains as the American Colony Hotel.

creator: Graves, James T., 1835-1914.
title: James T. Graves papers, 1841-1883 and undated.
context_snippet: , who was a solicitor of patents and a mechanical expert in Washington, D.C.
field_content: Collection comprises primarily physician bills and receipts for Dr. James T. Graves, along with a letter to Graves from his father (1875) regarding family matters, an undated partial page from an account book for the physician's personal expenses, and an business card for O. E. Duffy, who was a solicitor of patents and a mechanical expert in Washington, D.C.

creator: Parks, D. C. (David C.), 1834-1917.
title: David C. Parks letters, 1881-1888.
context_snippet: ) sent Parks a working stick from the Kings Mountain Revolutionary War battlefield as a memento and discussed amounts of tobacco
field_content: Collection comprises four letters written to D. C. Parks, one regarding a lien he held for property in Alabama (1881). Another announced his election to the Platonic Literary Society of Rutherford College (1883) and requested a liberal donation to help the Society furnish its hall. A third writer (1886) sent Parks a working stick from the Kings Mountain Revolutionary War battlefield as a memento and discussed amounts of tobacco shipped and received from Asheville, N. C., to Lynchburg, Va. A final writer (1888) requested that he rush to officially notarize a document to hold a third party to the agreement.

creator: Vela Piskova Midwifery Institute.
title: Vela Piskova Midwifery Institute presentation photograph album, 1947-1948.
context_snippet: was named after a famous female organizer of the Bulgarian Revolutionary Workers' Movement, Vela Piskova (1889-1925
field_content: The Midwifery Institute in Sofia, Bulgaria, was named after a famous female organizer of the Bulgarian Revolutionary Workers' Movement, Vela Piskova (1889-1925).

creator: Adler, Leon S. (Leon Sidney), 1912-1990.
title: Leon S. Adler papers, 1943-1993.
context_snippet: ; the couple had two children. He was a successful manager of retail clothing stores. Adler became a Lieutenant
field_content: Leon S. Adler was the son of Marcus Mordechai Valentine Adler and Jeanette B Sternberger and was born in Lebanon, Ind., in 1912. He married Roslyn Woolf, known to the family as "Posy," in 1937; the couple had two children. He was a successful manager of retail clothing stores. Adler became a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy Reserves during World War II, eventually serving as a Communications and Public Information officer from Feb. 1945-Dec. 1945 aboard the U.S.S. Biloxi. He was among the first U.S. occupation forces that arrived in Hiroshima and Nagasaki following the dropping of the atomic bombs, and his photographic and written documentation was uncensored.

creator: Clark, William, 1770-1838. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50083307
title: William Clark Missouri Territory treasury receipts, 1810, 1815.
context_snippet: what became the state of Missouri. Clark was a planter and slaveholder. Along with Meriwether Lewis, Clark helped
field_content: William Clark was an American explorer, soldier, Indian agent, and territorial governor. A native of Virginia, he grew up in territorial Kentucky before later settling in what became the state of Missouri. Clark was a planter and slaveholder. Along with Meriwether Lewis, Clark helped lead the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803 to 1806 across the Louisiana Purchase to the Pacific Ocean, and claimed the Pacific Northwest for the United States. Before the expedition, he served in a militia and the United States Army. Afterward, he served in a militia and as governor of the Missouri Territory.

creator: Evans, Edward B. (Edward Benjamin), 1846-1922. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2007002293
title: Edward B. Evans letters, 1914.
context_snippet: officer who attained the rank of Major, was a distinguished philatelist, stamp collector, and philatelic journalist who resided
field_content: Edward Benjamin Evans (3 November 1846 - 21 March 1922), a British army officer who attained the rank of Major, was a distinguished philatelist, stamp collector, and philatelic journalist who resided at Longton Avenue, Sydenham, London. His philatelic specialization included Mauritius, the Confederate States of America, the Mulready envelopes, and the Indian feudatory states.

creator: Cause Marketing Forum, Inc.

field_content: Professional organization founded in 2002 by David Hessekiel to promote business-nonprofit collaboration and corporate sponsorship of social service campaigns. Halo Awards were established in 2003 to celebrate notable cause marketing campaigns.

creator: Demby, William. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n86140670
title: William Demby papers, 1986-2008.
field_content: Most notable in the William Demby Papers are his unfinished novel, "King Comus," and a lengthy interview transcript from 2008. The collection also contains miscellaneous correspondence from the 2000s, personal documents, and research.

creator: Crowson, Alice, 1857-1916.
title: Alice Crowson letters, 1881-1887 and undated.
context_snippet: skin inflammation, erysipelas. Crowson's uncle described his successful beekeeping in Texas, among other endeavors. A surprising
field_content: Collection comprises 28 letters received by Crowson from friends and Beeman family members, mainly cousins, in North Carolina, and an Uncle based in Texas. One of her closest friends, Eugenia Morrison, wrote spirited letters, and teased Alice about her marriage and having a child. Morrison also wrote of her own unwillingness to marry her own suitor and of over-excitement caused by her attendance at a Methodist revival. Courtship, marriage proposals, and the success of religious revivals were common topics, as were health matters, sewing and quilting, canning and preserving, the weather, the success of gardens and crops, and travel and visiting. Crowson's cousin, Clelia, described her suffering and treatments for asthma and her baby's treatment for and slow recovery from cholera. Other letters mentioned the skin inflammation, erysipelas. Crowson's uncle described his successful beekeeping in Texas, among other endeavors. A surprising number of letters mention the body weight of individuals, and one writer refers to Crowson's ongoing struggles with "the blues," possibly postpartum depression (11 Feb 1884). She received a letter from a friend who was attending the Southern Normal school in Lexington, N.C. Several of the final letters were written to offer condolences on her husband's death and her being forced to turn her rent her home.

creator: Peeples, Cincinnatus, 1816-1877.
title: Cincinnatus Peeples papers, 1839-1892.
context_snippet: result of legal action; one item involves pensions for Revolutionary War officers and their beneficiaries. Includes a few tickets
field_content: Collection comprises primarily legal documents and correspondence associated with Cincinnatus Peeples' work, and that of the Peeples & Howell law firm following his death. Items mainly deal with financial collections to be completed in Georgia as a result of legal action; one item involves pensions for Revolutionary War officers and their beneficiaries. Includes a few tickets for membership dues paid in various associations.

creator: Peeples, Cincinnatus, 1816-1877.
title: Cincinnatus Peeples papers, 1839-1892.
context_snippet: in 1839 in Augusta, Georia. He was a respected attorney and partner in the Peeples & Howell law firm
field_content: Cincinnatus Peeples was born in South Carolina in 1816 and died in 1877. He was admited to the bar in 1839 in Augusta, Georia. He was a respected attorney and partner in the Peeples & Howell law firm in Atlanta, Georgia. He also served as a state senator and became judge of the Atlanta Circuit. He married Eliza Jane Cabaniss (1830-1899) in 1850; the couple had several children.

creator: Tanner, Evans, 1796-
title: Evans Tanner business records and personal letters, 1830-1882.
context_snippet: in tobacco; it is unclear whether he was a planter himself.
field_content: Evans Tanner was a postmaster and merchant of Tanner's Store in Mecklenburg County, Va. Part of his business involved trade in tobacco; it is unclear whether he was a planter himself.

creator: Winston, Robert W. (Robert Watson), 1860-1944. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n91055735
title: Robert W. Winston speech to Raleigh Kiwanis Club, 1941 and undated.
context_snippet: Using sometimes colorful language, he provided anecdotes regarding several notable citizens, as well as Raleigh's move to be
field_content: Collection comprises Robert W. Winston's undated, annotated, typescript (18-page) speech regarding the development of Raleigh since the end of the Civil War. Also includes a typescript copy of the speech, created in 1941. Winston treated the topic "industrially and sociologically, but not historically." Using sometimes colorful language, he provided anecdotes regarding several notable citizens, as well as Raleigh's move to be known for more than just its penitentiary, insane asylum, and cemetery during the early part of the twentieth century.

creator: Hill, Robert A., 1943- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82094350 creator.
title: Robert A. Hill collection, 1890-2014.
context_snippet: and collected materials document a wide range of topics. Prominent subjects include biographical information, writings, and activities of
field_content: The major emphasis of the Hill Collection is The Marcus Garvey and Universal Negro Improvement Association Papers, a series of publications that Hill edited for over thirty years that compile more than 30,000 documents highlighting the influence and accomplishments of Garvey and the UNIA. The process of compiling the twelve volumes is reflected in Hill's collection of research materials from manuscripts, photocopies of microfilm and original sources, newspaper clippings, annotated printed materials, photographs, scholar's correspondence, FBI records, and annotated drafts from U.S. and international archives, universities, and libraries. Hill's research interests and collected materials document a wide range of topics. Prominent subjects include biographical information, writings, and activities of Marcus Garvey, his family, and his acquaintances, including wives Amy Ashwood Garvey and Amy Jacques Garvey and secretary Elinor White; the administration, political activities, and writings of the Universal Negro Improvement Association; biographical information regarding other African American political leaders, including W.E.B. Du Bois, Cyril V. Briggs, Bob Marley, William Pickens, Robert Athlyi Rogers, George Schuyler, and Alfred C. Sam; documentation surrounding Caribbean independence movements and subsequent interference by the U.S. government and corporations (including the United Fruit Company); the Rastafari movement; black nationalist groups and black separatist churches such as the African Methodist Episcopal Church, the African Orthodox Church, the Afro Athlican Constructive Church; Freedom of Information Act requests and other documentation collected by Hill regarding FBI and government surveillance of African American political activities during the mid-twentieth century; newspapers and literature circulated among African American communities, both by UNIA and other groups; and much more. The bulk of the research materials are reproductions. Original materials collected by Hill can be found in the Primary Sources (PS) series. The collection also contains Hill's personal papers, UCLA-related materials and correspondence, general research, presentations, and other writings. These documents include Hill's historical editions such as Marcus Garvey's The Black Man: A Monthly Magazine of Negro Thought and Opinion; Cyril V. Briggs' The Crusader; George S. Schuyler's Black Empire and Ethiopian Stories; and The FBI's RACON: Racial Conditions in the United States during World War II. The Jamaica Series contains research materials, subject files, transcripts, and FBI reports collected by Hill about the Rastafarianism and International Peacemakers Association movements in Jamaica between the 1950s and 2000s. A subset of this series is original photographs, a scrapbook, and other items produced by Reverend Claudius Henry and members of the International Peacemakers Association in Sandy Bay, Jamaica.

creator: Righter & Sutton Lumber Co.
title: Righter & Sutton Lumber Co. collection agent's letters, 1851-1858.
context_snippet: by lumber commission merchant John B. Cook. Letters discuss successful collections, but also detail the state of the businesses
field_content: Collection comprises 8 letters sent from Philadelphia by collection agents for the Righter & Sutton Lumber Co. All but one letter was composed by lumber commission merchant John B. Cook. Letters discuss successful collections, but also detail the state of the businesses contacted, the viability of the lumber trade, possible new accounts, and any legal actions taken.

creator: Tillery, John, 1810-
title: John Tillery papers, 1864-1870.
field_content: John Tillery was a prominent slaveholding farmer and resident of Halifax Co., N.C. Thomas H. Watson was a neighbor.

creator: Kirby, Reynold Marvin, 1790-1842. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n94073784
title: Army receipt for clothing at Fort Macon, 1834 January 17.
context_snippet: Marvin Kirby. Ephraim Kirby was an officer in the Revolutionary War. Reynold Kirby was a major in the U.
field_content: Reynold Marvin Kirby was born March 10, 1790 in Litchfield, Connecticut, the son of Ephraim Kirby and Ruth Marvin Kirby. Ephraim Kirby was an officer in the Revolutionary War. Reynold Kirby was a major in the U. S. Army, 1st. U. S. Artillery. He was a veteran of the War of 1812 and the Seminole Wars. His last assignment was as Commandant of Fort Sullivan from 1839-1842. He died there on October 7, 1842 of pleurisy after a brief illness. He married Mary Barclay Kirby (1811-1891) in 1831 in Richmond, Va. When Kirby died, she moved back to Richmond with their five children: David Barclay, Reynold Marvin, twins Edmund and Margaret Barclay, and Joseph Lee.

creator: J.P. Reynolds & Co. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2001068140
title: J. P. Reynolds & Co. letters, 1875-1876.
context_snippet: Philadelphia exposition. They also solicited written testimonials from other prominent veterans such as Ambrose Burnside, Rutherford B. Hayes,
field_content: In 1868 John P. Reynolds of Salem, Massachusetts, patented a system of displaying a veteran's service record as a work of art called an escutcheon. The general design of these escutcheons was a shield with portions designated to the veterans' ranks, positions, units, and the battles in which they participated. These lithographs and paintings ranged in price from $5 to as much as $125 or more. By 1875 Reynolds had taken on Walter C. Strickler as a partner, a relationship that ended after 1878. Strickler's role was traveling around the country selling escutcheons. In addition to contacting individual veterans, he also made presentations at local G.A.R. posts and set up a display at the 1876 Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia. In an effort to attract new business, the company displayed the escutcheons of several well-known leaders, including Generals U.S. Grant, William T. Sherman, and Philip Sheridan at the Philadelphia exposition. They also solicited written testimonials from other prominent veterans such as Ambrose Burnside, Rutherford B. Hayes, Joshua Chamberlain, and John F. Hartranft. It is unclear how long Reynolds & Co. continued to produce escutcheons, but by 1888, Strickler had formed a competing company (Army and Navy Escutcheon Company) and had been discharged by the board of directors for poor management. The new company was sold to F. H. Dyer of Detroit, Michigan.

creator: Ferrell, Timothy K. (Timothy King) 1813-1856.
title: Timothy K. Ferrell letters, 1839-1844.
context_snippet: especially their Father; in later letters they outline marriages celebrated and children born, describe the health of those closest
field_content: Collection comprises 28 letters written to Timothy K. Ferrell, primarily written by his sister, Mary, and her husband, Henry King. There are only two letters from his sister, Ellen Louisa, and one from G. H. Ferrell. Topics in Henry King's letters focus purely on business and legal matters, his own and Timothy's, including land and commodity prices, the scarcity of money, and banking hardships. They contain extensive advice regarding Timothy's management of the crops, farm, and animals, as well as how to build his house and barn. King also transferred business affairs to Timothy for completion, primarily so that Timothy would have cash on hand to build his farm. King mentioned traveling to Washington, D.C., to check the government's records of his land holdings. Topics in his sisters' letters initially focus on the death of their mother and it's impact on the family, especially their Father; in later letters they outline marriages celebrated and children born, describe the health of those closest to them and any accidents suffered, mention the businesses of friends and how well they are doing, and occasionally discuss politics, particularly the 1840 presidential race. Includes two family letters written to Mary King from William N. Packhard, regarding the health of a family member.

creator: Cables, James H. (James Harvey), 1842-1924.
title: James Harvey Cables papers, 1792-1934 and undated.
context_snippet: to a monument for Col. William Bratton in the Revolutionary War; and three pages of printed poems. Contains
field_content: How the majority of the documents in the collection are related to James H. Cables is unclear. Collection primarily consists of legal documents for various North Carolina counties, including land deeds and indentures, summonses, and receipts. In addition, there are 8 letters to Cables and his family members, dated 1889-1934 and undated; an inaugural address by S. R. Hope before the Eumenean Society; a 1922-1923 report of the Ella C. Davidson Auxiliary in York, S.C.; an 1884 article on John C. Calhoun by C. L. Bratton; a Bratton family document relating to a monument for Col. William Bratton in the Revolutionary War; and three pages of printed poems. Contains a 1793 land survey for property held by John Holmes in Anson County, N.C.; an 1805 deed for William Parker regarding land in Rowan County, N.C.; an 1818 indenture for sale of land in Anson County to Roland Wilkerson by William Curlee; a deed for another land sale in 1819 by Wilkerson to Berry Austin; an 1823 deed for sale of land by Berry Austin in Anson County; an 1835 deed for Toddy Tolson in Anson County, along with another Tolson indenture dated 1827; a Frederick Carroll receipt dated 1827; an 1828 Iredell County summons for Harris Rouse; an 1843 Samson county summons for Nathan Williams and his 1842 promissory note; John L. Clifton receipts for 1845 and Bill for Injunction for 1849; a partial copy of Elizabeth Powell's dower dated 1852; and various receipts for Clifton family members dated 1867-1902.

creator: McCurdy (Family)
title: McCurdy family papers, 1852-1889 and undated.
context_snippet: the majority deal with the transfer of Archibald McCurdy's Revolutionary War pension to Elizabeth. Other items include an 8
field_content: Collection comprises primarily family and personal letters sent to and by members of the McCurdy family, several of which were love letters or were written regarding the continuation or cessation of relationships with the opposite sex. There is also a letter to Elizabeth, dated 1878, informing her that her father is doing well under his treatment at the Insane Asylum of North Carolina. Also present is a set of letters written by S. L. Jeffers and her husband, Frank, to her parents, but their relationship to the McCurdy's is not clear. In addition, includes business letters directed to Jacob M. McCurdy regarding land pensions and purchases, accounts, taxes, although the majority deal with the transfer of Archibald McCurdy's Revolutionary War pension to Elizabeth. Other items include an 8-pg manuscript song book, probably for guitar; an undated handwritten program for an instrumental music performance; several sets of travel instruction for areas around Salem, N.C.; and an undated copy of "Milns's Geographical Running Hand" copybook.

creator: Instituto Cubano de Amistad con los Pueblos. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no95037012
title: Cuban Institute for Friendship among the People letter, 1968 June 21.
context_snippet: , or open minded about, Cuba's post-revolutionary ambitions and concerned about possible counterrevolutionary invasion by the United
field_content: The Instituto Cubano de Amistad con los Pueblos (Cuban Institute for Friendship among the People, ICAP), a non-government organization founded in 1960, was established in Cuba soon after the early successes of the Cuban revolution. The purpose of ICAP was to reach out to the international community and form ties of friendship between Cuba and citizens of other countries who were either sympathetic to, or open minded about, Cuba's post-revolutionary ambitions and concerned about possible counterrevolutionary invasion by the United States.

creator: Anthony, Susan B. (Susan Brownell), 1820-1906, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82096260 correspondent.
title: Susan B. Anthony collection, 1870-1900.
context_snippet: Lathrop's inability to send more money following Anthony's successful speaking engagement there; the money went toward advertising for
field_content: Collection comprises seven letters from Susan B. Anthony to various correspondents, one postcard written to her, a printed item, and a letter by S.J.S. Holden that mentions Anthony, Stanton, and the 1874 National Woman Suffrage Association (N.W.S.A.) convention. In June 1870, Anthony wrote two letters to Edwin A. Studwell, who became her business manager, regarding payment for lectures in which she participated with Elizabeth Cady Stanton; her need to sell her serial, The Revolution, and plans for its continued success; competition with suffragists in Boston; her life insurance policies; and her general need for ready funds. There is also a Dec. 1873 letter from Anthony to Judge Henry R. Selden requesting copy for his argument made on Anthony's behalf regarding the Rights of Women in the U.S. District Court of New York, to be published in time for the upcoming N.W.S.A. convention. The postscript to this letter was written upon a flyer for a mass meeting of the New York Woman's Suffrage Society. Collection includes a copy of the final, printed version of Selden's argument, "Rights of women under the late constitutional amendments." In 1894, Anthony wrote two letters to a suffragist concerning problems in Kansas; she wished to identify the Republican, Progressive, or other person responsible for "stirring things up," for the Republicans failed to include suffrage in their platform. On 1900 April 24, Anthony wrote to Rachel [Foster Avery?] regarding several publications in process, including forms for letters to the national conventions of the prohibition, Populist, Democratic, and Republican parties; a "memorial;" an appeal to the Ecumenical Council; along with other work to be shared by the suffrage leadership. A letter from Anthony 1900 July 22 was written to an unnamed suffragist who likely requested an autograph, "Yes indeed--you shall have my pen tracks--not only--but also my wish that you both believe in work for the protection of women in the crowning right of citizenship--the right to vote--and so help to hasten the day when ours shall be a true republic in practice as it now is in theory." Collection also includes a postcard written to Anthony from Mary L. Lathrop in Jackson, [Miss.?] in 1874 regarding Lathrop's inability to send more money following Anthony's successful speaking engagement there; the money went toward advertising for the event. Another letter, from S.J.S. Holden to Rachel [Foster Avery?], in 1874 describes attendance at the N.W.S.A. convention, the speeches of Anthony and Elizabeth Cay Stanton, and other pastimes in Washington, D.C. Several of the letters in the collection are written on N.W.S.A. or National-American Woman Suffrage Association letterhead; Anthony's 1894 letters are stamped with the ownership mark of the Daughters of the Pioneers of Washington library. Collection includes dealer transcriptions for two of Anthony's letters.

creator: Stowe, Harriet Beecher, 1811-1896. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79093331
title: Harriet Beecher Stowe papers, 1853 and undated.
context_snippet: reached millions as a novel and play, and became influential in the United States and United Kingdom. It energized
field_content: Harriet Elisabeth Beecher Stowe (1811 June 14-1896 July 1) was an American abolitionist and author. Her novel Uncle Tom's Cabin (1852) was a depiction of life for African Americans under slavery; it reached millions as a novel and play, and became influential in the United States and United Kingdom. It energized anti-slavery forces in the American North, while provoking widespread anger in the South. She wrote more than 20 books, including novels, three travel memoirs, and collections of articles and letters. She was influential for both her writings and her public stands on social issues of the day.

creator: Stowe, Harriet Beecher, 1811-1896. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79093331
title: Harriet Beecher Stowe papers, 1853 and undated.
context_snippet: , and collections of articles and letters. She was influential for both her writings and her public stands on social
field_content: Harriet Elisabeth Beecher Stowe (1811 June 14-1896 July 1) was an American abolitionist and author. Her novel Uncle Tom's Cabin (1852) was a depiction of life for African Americans under slavery; it reached millions as a novel and play, and became influential in the United States and United Kingdom. It energized anti-slavery forces in the American North, while provoking widespread anger in the South. She wrote more than 20 books, including novels, three travel memoirs, and collections of articles and letters. She was influential for both her writings and her public stands on social issues of the day.

creator: Becker, Albert (Al), creator.
title: Al Becker scrapbook, 1932-1941.
context_snippet: and goals, and congratulatory messages to Becker for managing successful Baker's and Burt women's shoe and hosiery stores
field_content: Scrapbook consists primarily of letters from regional and corporate managers discussing seasonal promotions, sales figures and goals, and congratulatory messages to Becker for managing successful Baker's and Burt women's shoe and hosiery stores. Also includes copies of photographs and greeting cards. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

creator: Maxwell, Martha, 1831-1881, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n81125838 associated name.
title: Martha Maxwell photographs and clipping, 1875-1877 and undated.
context_snippet: the treated skins over them. Her display was so celebrated that she was invited to show her pieces at the
field_content: Martha Maxwell, also known as "The Colorado Huntress," was an American naturalist, hunter, taxidermist, and author. She was born in Pennsylvania, and moved to Colorado as a bride. After seeing the work of a local taxidermist, she studied the art and began accompanying her husband on hunting trips. After shooting native birds and mammals, she prepared them for exhibit by reconstructing their frames in plaster and stretching the treated skins over them. Her display was so celebrated that she was invited to show her pieces at the Centennial Exhibition in Philadelphia.

creator: Traffic Audit Bureau (New York, N.Y.) http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n87841236
title: Women's Social and Political Union scrapbook, 1908-1917 and undated.
context_snippet: resulting in forced feedings), for breaking windows in prominent buildings, and for night-time arson of unoccupied
field_content: The Women's Social and Political Union (W.S.P.U.) was the leading militant organization campaigning for women's suffrage in the United Kingdom, 1903-1917, and was a breakaway organization from the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies. Its membership and policies were tightly controlled by Emmeline Pankhurst and her daughters, Christabel and Sylvia. It was best known for hunger strikes (resulting in forced feedings), for breaking windows in prominent buildings, and for night-time arson of unoccupied houses and churches.

creator: White, Robert, collector.
title: Robert White collection of Chinese Cultural Revolution materials, 1920s-1993 and undated.
context_snippet: prominently featured on the majority of the posters; another notable figure is Lin Biao. Other figures represented include Mao
field_content: Collection consists of posters, pins, buttons, flags, printed materials and publications (including Little Red Books), objects and ephemera, most featuring representations of Mao, acquired by White in the 1980s-1990s while he participated in academic exchanges with China during his research at Appalachian State University and Duke University. Most of the materials were created and printed in China and intended for the Chinese public. A small number of printed items were intended for an American or global audience, printed in English by the government's Foreign Languages Press. The majority of items were produced during the Cultural Revolution period, and celebrate or promote the ideals and persona of Mao Zedong. Other themes or events idealized in this collection include the creation of political collectives around the country; the establishment of the Red Guard; army service; atomic power; traditional farming; the Down to the Countryside Movement; the Foolish Old Man fable; and other political events and personas within the Chinese Communist Party during the mid-twentieth century. Other noteable references include the Three Red Banners; the Sixteen Points program; the Red Guards' eight mass rallies in Tiananmen Square in Beijing during 1966; Quotations from Chairman Mao Tse-tung (also known as the Little Red Book); and community performances, particularly the 8 Model Plays. Mao is prominently featured on the majority of the posters; another notable figure is Lin Biao. Other figures represented include Mao's wife Jiang Qing, exiled Cambodian king Norodom Sihanouk, as well as pre-Cultural Revolution leaders Liu Shaoqi, Zhou Enlai, and Hua Guofeng.

creator: Faraday, Michael, 1791-1867. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50009174
title: Michael Faraday letters, 1863 January 30, 1865 April 1.
context_snippet: to a Covent Garden show: Frederick Gye was the prominent manager for the Royal Italian Opera productions. Acquired as
field_content: The collection consists of two letters written by Michael Faraday, English physicist and resident of the Royal Institution of Great Britain, toward the end of his life. One letter is addressed to the Duchess of Northumberland, thanking her for her generosity and asking if she might send Faraday something in return, apparently a photograph of herself. The other is addressed to an "F. Gye," also thanking him for a gift, most likely tickets to a Covent Garden show: Frederick Gye was the prominent manager for the Royal Italian Opera productions. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: Womankind Books (Bookstore), http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2016137199 creator.
title: Unidentified family photograph album, approximately 1850-1897.
field_content: Collection comprises a photograph album maintained by an unidentified wealthy, possibly British, family; handwritten captions appear in several different hands. The 159 photographs either document family travel as souvenirs, or document both their travel and photograph collecting, because many of the photographs are albumen prints by famous late-19th-century photographers, including Bonfils, Zangaki, Samuel Bourne, Francis Frith, and others not identified except by the presence of their negative numbers and captions on the photograph. From these photographers there are images of Israel; Syria; Palestine; Jerusalem; Athens, Greece; and Agra, India, along with photographs of statues and other artifacts recovered in archaeological digs. Other photographs in the album were probably taken by family members, first in Venice, then in various places, including Scotland, England, and Jamaica. Among these photographs are albumen and cyanotype prints. Photographs in the album date somewhere between 1850 and 1897, and range in size from 1.5 x 2-inches to 8.5 x 11.5 inches. A list of photographs has been housed with the item. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts.

creator: Phelps, Leland R., http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82039406 collector.
title: Medical postage stamps collection, 1940s-1980s and undated, bulk 1960-1970s.
context_snippet: over one hundred countries around the world. Stamps feature notable physicians and scientists, anniversaries of medical events, medicinal
field_content: Consists of medical stamps collected by unknown person, from over one hundred countries around the world. Stamps feature notable physicians and scientists, anniversaries of medical events, medicinal plants, efforts to combat diseases and addictions, women in science, medical organizations, and other topics in the history of medicine. Stamps are stored in labeled glassine envelopes, and accompanied by the ATA Handbook No. 63, Vol. 3, Medical Stamps, 1968, which contains lists of historical medical stamps and special topics. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: North, Marianne, 1830-1890, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80060872 creator.
title: Marianne North letter to Dr. Jessop, undated.
context_snippet: North was an English Victorian biologist and botanical artist, notable for her plant and landscape paintings, her extensive foreign
field_content: Marianne North was an English Victorian biologist and botanical artist, notable for her plant and landscape paintings, her extensive foreign travels, her writings, her plant discoveries and the creation of her gallery at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.

creator: Sigourney, L. H. (Lydia Howard), 1791-1865, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80010427 secretary.
title: Certificate of proof for smallpox vaccination, 1872 August 20.
context_snippet: 1872, and the date when the vaccination was declared successful and the certificate signed by the physician, a Professor
field_content: Printed form in German language for proof of smallpox vaccination, filled out in manuscript hand with the name of the patient, a P[?] Maurer, 49 years of age, and the date of vaccination, August 12, 1872, and the date when the vaccination was declared successful and the certificate signed by the physician, a Professor Zelinder, August 20, 1872. The entry for the location may be Balaton, Hungary. In 1872 there was a very severe smallpox outbreak in England; in 1874, a compulsory vaccination law went into effect in Germany. The certificate bears a decorative border and a small shield. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

creator: Méndez, Juan E., http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n82242450 creator.
title: Juan Méndez papers, 1980-2017 and undated.
context_snippet: engagements, consultancies, and leadership roles as a global expert on transitional justice, torture, and genocide. The
field_content: The collection consists of materials documenting Méndez's work with the United Nations and ICTJ (2004-2017), as well as a small portion of his writings and professional engagements (dating approximately 2005-2012). Méndez's policy work as the UN Special Advisor for the Prevention of Genocide and the UN Special Rapporteur on Torture represent the bulk of the collection. There is a smaller amount of administrative and event-related materials documenting his work while president of the International Center for Transitional Justice, as well as a selection of files from his various speaking engagements, consultancies, and leadership roles as a global expert on transitional justice, torture, and genocide. The collection includes a substantial amount of materials documenting the UN's approach to the Darfur crisis, including policy statements, reports from the Sudanese government, research, and visits to the region by Méndez and the UN High Commissioner on Human Rights. Méndez's files from his role as UN Special Rapporteur on Torture, and Other Cruel, Inhuman, and Degrading Treatment and Punishment also contain subject and country files, administrative and conference notes about meetings with various UN officials and NGOs, a selection of files about specific legal cases Méndez was involved in as the SRT, and documentation about assorted country visits and missions. There is a small amount of material relating to United States' policies on solitary confinement, as well as materials about the WikiLeaks and Bradley Manning case. Acquired as part of the Human Rights Archive (Duke University).

creator: Weiss family, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2015066855 collector.
title: Charles and Shirley Weiss collection of opera ephemera, 1951-2003.
context_snippet: performance, date, location, performers, and other notable information about each program. The opera programs included represent
field_content: Collection consists of 1386 opera programs collected from around the world by Charles and Shirley Weiss between 1951 and 2003. The programs are also detailed in a spreadsheet, documenting performance, date, location, performers, and other notable information about each program. The opera programs included represent a range of performances including classic, contemporary, and lesser-known operas. Venues are from around the world.

creator: Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (U.S.). http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50010550 Atlanta Regional Office, photographer.
title: Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee photographs, 1960s.
context_snippet: Coordinating Committee (SNCC) was one of the most important organizations of the American Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s
field_content: The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) was one of the most important organizations of the American Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s. It emerged from a student meeting organized by Ella Baker held at Shaw University in April 1960. SNCC grew into a large organization with many supporters in the North who helped raise funds to support SNCC's work in the South, allowing full-time SNCC workers to have a $10 per week salary. Many unpaid volunteers also worked with SNCC on projects in Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, Arkansas, and Maryland. SNCC played a major role in the sit-ins and freedom rides, a leading role in the 1963 March on Washington, Mississippi Freedom Summer, and the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party over the next few years. SNCC's major contribution was in its field work, organizing voter registration drives all over the South, especially in Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi.

creator: John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2014022033
title: John Hope Franklin ephemera collection, 2015-2018.
context_snippet: history. He wrote From Slavery to Freedom, the seminal work on African American history, which was first published
field_content: John Hope Franklin was a historian specializing in Southern and African American history. He wrote From Slavery to Freedom, the seminal work on African American history, which was first published in 1947. In the course of his career, Franklin had professorships at St. Augustine College, North Carolina College, Howard University, Brooklyn College, University of Chicago, and Duke University. He served as president of numerous historical and community organizations throughout his career. President Clinton awarded him the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1995. Franklin also served on President Clinton's Advisory Board for the President's Initiative on Race from 1997 to 1998. He died in 2009.

creator: Carter, Lin, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n50033947 creator.
title: Lin Carter papers, 1900s-2001.
field_content: Linwood Vrooman Carter was a prolific American author of science fiction and fantasy, as well as an editor, poet and critic. He usually wrote as Lin Carter; known pseudonyms include H. P. Lowcraft and Grail Undwin.

creator: Woolf, Virginia, 1882-1941, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79041870 correspondent.
title: Virginia Woolf letter and photograph, around 1930.
context_snippet: an English writer and publisher, and one of the foremost modernists of the twentieth century.
field_content: Virginia Woolf was an English writer and publisher, and one of the foremost modernists of the twentieth century.

creator: Woolf, Virginia, 1882-1941, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79041870 correspondent.
title: Emmeline and Frederick Pethick-Lawrence papers, 1908-1946.
context_snippet: as a result of their activism. Emmeline was a prominent member of the Women's International League for Peace during
field_content: Emmeline and Frederick Pethick-Lawrence were British socialist activists heavily involved with both the suffrage and peace movements. They started the weekly publication Votes for Women in 1907; Emmeline also published pamphlets based on her suffrage speeches, and a 1938 autobiography. They were members of the Women's Social and Political Union and later, the United Suffragists. The couple served prison sentences as a result of their activism. Emmeline was a prominent member of the Women's International League for Peace during WWI, and Frederick was a founding member of the peace organization Union of Democratic Control. Later, Frederick served as a Labour politician who worked on behalf of Indian independence.

creator: Glazer, Harry Bernard (Harrison Bernard), 1923-2014, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2016107039 creator.
title: Harry Bernard Glazer papers, 1932-1972 and undated.
context_snippet: his repeated rejection by the Selective Service, his eventual successful enlistment in the army in 1943, and his early
field_content: The collection consists of Harry Glazer's diaries and correspondence, as well as some personal materials from both Harry and his brother David Glazer, dating from the early 1930s but extending through the 1970s. The majority of the material dates from the 1940s, while Harry was a student and enlisted soldier in World War II; additional materials date from the 1970s while Harry was serving in the Foreign Service during the Vietnam War. Harry kept thorough and legible diaries; the collection contains diaries from both the World War II-era and the Vietnam War-era. The early diaries (1941-1944) document his last year of high school at Woodrow Wilson High School in Washington, D.C., his repeated rejection by the Selective Service, his eventual successful enlistment in the army in 1943, and his early days of training at North Camp Hood and Camp Bowie in Texas. There is also a diary from 1971 kept by Harry while he was stationed in Vietnam as part of the Foreign Service, describing his activities, his feelings about his work and the broader activities of the U.S. soldiers, his homesickness and love for his family, and the conditions he witnessed in Vietnam. There are several periods represented in the collection's correspondence. The bulk of the World War II-era correspondence consists of letters between Harry, David, and their parents, but there are also letters between Harry, his fellow soldiers, and his friends, including girlfriends. There is also a large amount of outgoing correspondence (including love notes, family news, and reports on Vietnam) from 1970-1972 from Harry to his wife, Carol, written while he was stationed in Vietnam. Incoming letters from Harry's children, Debbie and David, also date from that period. Finally, there is a series of letters from Harry's father, Morris, to his mother, Dorothy, dating from 1932-1933, written while Morris was traveling for business. The collection has a significant amount of material, including correspondence and medical logs, relating to Harry's brother David Glazer's illnesses and his death in 1945. The other materials in the collection relate to Harry's participation and leadership in local Wendell Willkie clubs for the 1940 election; Harry's army service during World War II, including some printed materials from his attendance at Jewish services while in the U.S. Army in Europe after the war ended in 1945. The collection's content documents Harry Glazer's ongoing interest in international affairs, especially the treatment of Jews in Europe; America's role in the war, including detailed news accounts; his pre-Army daily activities, including school, jobs, friends, and hobbies; his personal feelings over his struggle to enlist; his tumultuous relationships with his parents (including his diary entries documenting abuse by his father); his concern and love for his brother, David, a bright student and Boy Scout who suffered from ongoing medical problems; his attendance at Jewish services and observances of Jewish holidays; his various relationships, courtships, and communications with several women; his marriage to Carol and his relationship with his children; his work and service in the Army, including his training exercises and troop movements; his desires and career aspirations following the war; and a set of color Kodachrome slides taken while he was serving in Vietnam.

creator: Chipman, John Somerset, 1926- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n80076463 creator.
title: John S. Chipman papers, 1948-2014 and undated.
context_snippet: writings, and teachings at the University of Minnesota. Prominent themes include international trade, with extensive research on West
field_content: Chipman's papers consist of drafts, publications, lecture notes, correspondence, and other files documenting his scholarship, writings, and teachings at the University of Minnesota. Prominent themes include international trade, with extensive research on West Germany during the Cold War; linear programming; welfare economics; econometrics; the writings and impact of Vilfredo Pareto; and Chipman's collaboration and friendships with other economists. The range of Chipman's research and writings are represented in the Writings Series, where files typically include drafts and published versions, usually offprints, as well as occasional correspondence and notes by Chipman documenting the development of the paper or essay. The Name Files series includes a variety of material (including correspondence, writings, notes, and subject files) that document his professional relationships and communications with publishers, professional organizations, or other scholars, as well as his ongoing collaboration with other economists, including Leonid Hurwicz, James C. Moore, Tjalling Koopmans, Paul Samuelson, Eugen Slutsky, and Ragnar Frisch. The Engagements series includes Chipman's lecture notes, exams, and reading lists from his years as a professor in the Economics Department, as well as event files from conferences, workshops, travels, awards, and other activities over the course of his career as an economist. Forms part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.

creator: Cox, Robert John, 1933- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2002041651 creator.
title: Robert J. Cox papers, 1879-2010.
context_snippet: . Cox married Maud Daverio, who came from a prominent Buenos Aires family. They had five children. At
field_content: Robert Cox was born in England in 1933 and came to Buenos Aires as a young man in 1959. He worked as a journalist and eventually became the editor of the Buenos Aires Herald, the largest English-language newspaper in Argentina. Cox married Maud Daverio, who came from a prominent Buenos Aires family. They had five children. At the Buenos Aires Herald, Cox wrote about the disappearances of left wing activists and extremists who were targeted by the Argentine military. He continued to cover the violence of the Dirty War even while receiving personal threats. Cox was honored with the Maria Moors Cabot Prize in 1978 for his reporting on Latin America. Cox and his family fled Argentina in 1979 after his son Peter received an anonymous, detailed threat. After holding other positions, including a Nieman Fellowship at Harvard University, Cox become the assistant editor at The Post and Courier in Charleston, South Carolina. While in the United States, Cox continued to publish stories about the political landscape of Argentina as well. He also wrote at length about political violence in Central America and Cuba. In 2008, his son David Cox published a book about his father's journalistic career in Argentina entitled Dirty Secrets, Dirty War: The Exile of Robert J. Cox (Buenos Aires, Argentina: 1976-1983). The Buenos Aires Herald closed in 2017.

creator: Kirk, Edward Norris, 1802-1874, http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no89009120 correspondent.
title: Edward Norris Kirk papers, 1829-1865.
context_snippet: missionary Jonas King; minister, abolitionist, and "Father of Modern Revivalism" Charles Grandison Finney; clergyman and author
field_content: Collection comprises one letter written by Kirk in 1861 to reject an invitation, and six letters written to him. Correspondents include abolitionist editor Joshua Leavitt; musician and hymn composer Thomas Hastings; missionary Jonas King; minister, abolitionist, and "Father of Modern Revivalism" Charles Grandison Finney; clergyman and author William Jenks; and a neighbor, G. R. Buckland. Topics include a sermon by Finney on "true" Christian belief and Kirk's evangelistic plans; a request for Kirk's appearance at a benefit; an introduction for a Greek revolutionary, Michael Kalopothakes; the mission to the Armenians; and placement of two young people.

creator: McCarty, Lisa, 1982- http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2017041492 teacher.
title: Raymond C. Battalio and John B. Van Huyck papers, 1972-2014 and undated.
context_snippet: professional activities, particularly their work as experimental economists and influential figures in developing the field of experimental economics during the
field_content: The Raymond C. Battalio and John B. Van Huyck Papers document their careers as economists at Texas A & M University. The collection consists of their correspondence, writings, and research; and provides an overview of their professional activities, particularly their work as experimental economists and influential figures in developing the field of experimental economics during the 1990s. The papers of Battalio and Van Huyck are combined as one collection given their close working relationship. Their joint work focused on a series of experiments showing the likeliness of coordination failures even when incentives guide participants to attempt to coordinate - the aim being to highlight the difficulty of economic coordination. The collection also includes Battalio and Van Huyck's communications with other prominent contributors to experimental economics such as Colin Camerer, Charles Holt, John Kagel, Thomas Palfrey, Ariel Rubinstein, Alvin Roth, Larry Samuelson, and Vernon Smith, among others. The collection also documents Battalio and Van Huyck's roles in the Economic Science Association and Van Huyck's as an editor of Experimental Economics, and their department roles, committee work, and teaching contributions in economics at Texas A & M. Forms part of the Economists' Papers Archive at Duke University.
